report_title: Concrete Reinforcing Bar Manufacturing Industry Report
executive_summary: The Concrete Reinforcing Bar Manufacturing industry produces concrete reinforcing bars, also known as rebar, and bar joists. Industry products are made of steel and installed in concrete during pouring to increase its strength and prevent cracking; therefore, they are found in nearly all concrete structures. Over the five years to 2022, construction activity has declined, which led to decreased demand from the domestic market, with major declines primarily experienced in 2020 due to the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic. In addition, although steel prices have increased over the past five years, its volatility has enabled operators to raise their selling prices. Decreased import penetration has slightly eased the high level of price-based competition in this industry. Overall, industry revenue has increased at an annualized rate of 5.7% to $17.9 billion over the five years to 2022, despite a decrease of 7.3% in 2022 alone, fueled in part by an expected steep decrease in steel prices.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Construction sector consumes nearly all rebar produced by this industry. Rebar is employed to reinforce commercial, industrial, residential, institutional and public utility concrete structures.

Over the five years to 2022, the value of private nonresidential construction has decreased, with a major decline occurring in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic as demand from global and commercial markets fell.

Roadways are another major source of demand for rebar. Concrete is used for many bridges and overpasses. Rebar is critical for creating functional highway structures due to its resistance to lateral forces.
Steel is the industry's single-largest input material. Global steel prices have a direct effect on rebar prices as operators must adjust prices based on input costs to remain competitive.
Profit has increased during the period due to rising steel prices helping operators plan cost structures efficiently, accounting for 6.3% of revenue in 2022, up from 5.3% in 2017.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Fortunately for industry operators, nonresidential construction markets are expected to continue growing, which will likely further bolster industry performance moving forward. The industrial production index is also expected to rise, growing an annualized 1.4% over the five years to 2027, boosting demand for industrial structures. Additionally, the value of private nonresidential construction is expected to rise at an annualized rate of 1.8% during the same period. In particular, greater corporate profit, improving business confidence and consumer spending will likely support industry growth.

Consolidation trends experienced over the five years to 2022 are expected to continue during the outlook period as large manufacturers attempt to reap the benefits from economies of scale and a high level of automation. These practices enable more established operators to reduce costs and improve profit, and enable big companies to acquire small ones. However, due to increased demand for industry products from downstream markets, the number of industry operators is forecast to increase, rising at an annualized rate of 1.5% to 1,381 companies over the five years to 2027.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Recovery in Exports, Continued Low Import Penetration
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The value of imports is expected to decrease slightly, falling at an annualized rate of 0.5% to $1.0 billion over the next five years. In line with this trend, imports' share of demand is expected to decrease slightly, satisfying 5.5% of domestic demand in 2027, down from 5.6% in 2022. Although imports may influence the price of domestically made rebar, slower domestic demand and decreasing steel prices will likely have a negative effect. Furthermore, the US dollar is expected to depreciate slightly over the next five years, making imports more expensive for domestic customers and decreasing their pricing advantage over domestically produced products.

industry_definition: This industry produces concrete reinforcing bars, also known as rebar, which are steel rods installed inside concrete to increase its tensile strength and prevent cracking. Rebar is therefore found in a large percentage of concrete structures and is used heavily across construction markets. This industry also produces bar joists, which are similar in use but consist of an open web of a single bent bar running in zigzag pattern.
key_trends: Government consumption and investment has risen, supporting industry revenue growth
Profit has increased during the period due to rising steel prices
Exports have suffered due to the strength of the dollar

Industry employment is expected to rise slightly, in contrast to industry participation trends

market_segmentation.segment_description: Transport infrastructure construction encompasses the erection of highways, tunnels, bridges and railways, among other products. Concrete reinforcing bars and joists, which run between beams to support ceiling and floor structures, are both vital to infrastructure-related construction.

market_segmentation.segment: Utilities infrastructure and nonresidential building construction
market_segmentation.segment_description: Utilities infrastructure encompasses the erection of electrical transmission lines and radio transmission lines, and therefore, relies heavily on fabricated metal towers. Other utilities infrastructure includes water and sewage systems and depends on concrete reinforcing bars, cyclones, ducting, piping, sterilizing chambers and tunnel lining.
The export of industry products, primarily to Canada and emerging economies, generates an estimated 2.5% of industry revenue in 2022, decreasing as a share of revenue over the past five years.

products_and_services.product_description: Long span rebar generally exceeds 30.0 feet in length, and commercial and government building projects often require longer rebar to secure concrete. In addition to needing longer rebar, larger construction projects often require additional strengthening measures, such as corrosion prevention.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Short Rebar and Joists for Industrial Construction
products_and_services.product_description: Short rebar is generally less than 30.0 feet in length and is mostly used in the construction of industrial buildings, which are often small or medium-sized plants or warehouses.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The largest purchaser of structural metals is the commercial construction industry, which comprises multiple segments that are each influenced by different demand factors. Office construction is primarily determined by growth in the service sector workforce, growth in foreign investment inflow and speculative developer activity.

Federal, state and local government investments in institutions and infrastructure also influence demand for concrete reinforcing bars. Public investment in schools, medical centers and religious centers generates significant demand for rebar products; in addition, these projects often source rebar solely from domestic sources, circumventing imports.

Demand for residential construction is subject to both short-term and long-term influences. The short-term influences include movements in interest rates, housing affordability and stimulatory government policy. The long-term influences include population growth and settlement, the aging of existing stock and buyer preferences between single-family and multifamily style housing.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports represent a key market for rebar manufacturers in the United States. The value of imports has increased at an annualized rate of 3.6% to $1.6 billion over the five years to 2022. Mexico is the largest source of imports and supplies fabricated structural metal products and sells back to the United States.

Exports represent a weak market for rebar manufacturers in the United States. The value of exports has declined at an annualized rate of 2.2% to $443.8 million over the five years to 2022, which is primarily due to weak international demand for steel, particularly from China.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region is home to 25.9% of the US population in 2022, mirroring the percentage of industry establishments located within the region. Demand from this region comes from commercial builders catering to metropolitan populations and industrial builders catering to the variety of sectors present in the Southeast.

The Great Lakes region accounts for 14.3% of the US population in 2022. The region is home to numerous commercial construction projects demanding rebar products. However, it is also a hub of automotive and other manufacturing industries, which use reinforcing bar, or rebar, to erect industrial buildings.

The Southwest accounts for 15.0% of industry establishments in 2022, most of which are located in Texas, which accounts for 10.6% of establishments in 2022. Texas is home to major industry operators, such as Commercial Metals Company. Large demand from Texas is related to oil refining and drilling industries, which purchase rebar for constructing plants, refineries and utilities infrastructure.

The West region accounts for 12.0% of industry establishments in 2022, more than half of which are located in California, which accounts for 7.4% of locations. California is a heavily populated state with demand for rebar for commercial, institutional and residential buildings. It is also home to a variety of industries, including food processing industries, which require rebar products for erecting plants and facilities.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Operators are required to comply with regulations set by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) on emission of pollutants.
The National Institute for Metalworking Skills has developed industry-wide standards for metalworking machine operators.
The Trump administration prioritized revitalizing US manufacturing by reconsidering trade agreements deemed unfair for US competition.
Various regulations have been implemented due to the coronavirus pandemic to discourage public gathering and crowded work environments.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The revenue volatility level is very high.
The industry assistance level is low and increasing.
The competition level is high and increasing.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition among operators is high given the similarity of products and market saturation, reflected in low profits due to aggressive price competition.
External competition comes from substitute materials like wood, plastics and fiberglass used in non-concrete construction projects.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The top 3 companies generate 45.4% of revenue in 2022, representing moderate concentration.
Consolidation has moderately increased over 5 years due to larger companies expanding through mergers/acquisitions and smaller companies exiting.
Concentration is expected to lessen over next 5 years due to more companies entering, offset by acquisitions by larger companies.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The largest cost segment for operators in the Concrete Reinforcing Bar Manufacturing industry is purchases, which is primarily made up of steel raw material inputs.
Profit has fluctuated over the five years to 2022, as revenue growth is countered by volatility in steel prices, making it difficult for operators to optimally plan their cost structures.
Enterprises in this industry operate with little profit due to high competition, the homogeneity of the product offered and the pressure to compete primarily on the basis of price.
Wages as a share of revenue are relatively high due to the labor-intensive nature of this industry.
Increased automation of the manufacturing process will likely enable industry operators to reduce their labor costs in the future.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Large producers operate with more capital-intensive processes
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Large producers tend to operate with more capital-intensive production processes, as a large portion of rebar manufacturing is automated.
Remelting, continuous casting, twisting, adding grooves, cooling and cutting can all be handled without manual labor.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Although demand for construction has increased consistently over most of the five years to 2022, the significant volatility in steel prices has led to revenue fluctuations during the period.
The industry has experienced revenue increase as much as 13.6% in 2018. In 2020, revenue declined 5.9%, but increased 32.8% in 2021 alone.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The Concrete Reinforcing Bar Manufacturing industry exhibits a low level of technological change, with rebar manufacturing processes remaining largely the same over the past decade.
The biggest change affecting this industry has been the gradual incorporation of automation into the manufacturing process.
Computer-controlled saws, lasers, shears and presses are used to cut and form parts, with automated machinery able to replace low-skill workers.
However, the basic production process of melting, shaping, grooving and varnishing remains the same.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Import penetration is still low due to the difficulty of shipping rebar overseas.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: This industry's revenue is heavily dependent on construction activity, which is closely tied to the overall economy.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers tend to locate close to their downstream buyers, due to the hard-to-transport nature of the product.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Steel prices have been very volatile over the past few years, causing swings in revenue and reducing profit.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Larger operators have automated certain operators, but smaller operators are still largely dependent on manual labor and certain processes cannot be automated.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in technology, such as 3D printing, to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Larger and more established companies have been investing in automation to reduce labor costs.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Trade associations such as the American Institute of Steel Construction enable companies to gain access to industry relevant resources.

FAQs.question: What effect have international tariffs had on your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Rebar is covered under the recent set of steel tariffs, significantly reducing imports and exposing exports to retaliatory tariffs.

FAQs.question: How has price volatility of inputs affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: The volatility of steel prices have tempered profit growth.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: There is a high level of price-based competition that pushes profit margins down in this industry.

FAQs.question: Do you have fixed, long-term contracts with input suppliers? How to you contend with fluctuations in input costs?
FAQs.answer: Some of the industry's major operators have vertically integrated, which enables them to be their own input supplier, while also reducing supply and distribution costs.

FAQs.question: Do you have a diverse range of clients, or are you a niche operator? How can you diversify your client base?
FAQs.answer: Due to the varying uses for products from this industry, operators must maintain a broad range of clients to protect revenue streams from sudden drops in downstream demand.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? What range does your company have in terms of viable operating area?
FAQs.answer: As the majority of products manufactured in this industry are standardized and interchangeable, customers are likely to buy from local manufacturers so they can minimize transport costs.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuating steel prices affect your company? Would you be able to pass on steel cost increases to your customers?
FAQs.answer: The trade-weighted index (TWI) measures the US currency's strength against that of its major trading partners. When the TWI increases and the value of the dollar is rising, industry exports are relatively less competitive in the global market.

FAQs.question: Do you track investments the government makes in your industry? How have fluctuations in government investments affected your company?
FAQs.answer: Government spending positively influences industry demand because it encourages additional spending on the concrete reinforced bars that are used during highway, road and bridge construction, as well as in public buildings and facilities.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in nonresidential construction?
FAQs.answer: Nonresidential construction generates the majority of demand for concrete reinforcing bars (rebar) and fabricated joists. Most commercial buildings, private schools and medical and religious centers are concrete-based, requiring rebar to even out the concrete and increase its tensile strength.
